thag19.1:1.1.eng: Oh, when will I stay in a mountain cave,

thag19.1:1.3.eng: discerning all states of existence as impermanent?

thag19.1:1.4.pli: Taṃ me idaṃ taṃ nu kadā bhavissati.
thag19.1:1.4.eng: This hope of mine, <j>when will it be?

thag19.1:2.1.eng: Oh, when will I stay happily in the forest,

thag19.1:2.2.eng: a sage wearing a torn robe, dressed in ocher,

thag19.1:2.3.eng: unselfish, with no need for hope,

thag19.1:2.4.eng: with greed, hate, and delusion destroyed?

thag19.1:3.1.eng: Oh, when will I stay alone in the wood,

thag19.1:3.2.eng: fearless, discerning this body as impermanent,

thag19.1:3.3.eng: a nest of death and disease,

thag19.1:3.4.pli: Eko vane taṃ nu kadā bhavissati.
thag19.1:3.4.eng: harried by death and old age; when will it be?

thag19.1:4.1.eng: Oh, when will I live, <j>having grasped the sharp sword of wisdom

thag19.1:4.2.eng: and cut the creeper of craving <j>that tangles around everything,

thag19.1:4.3.eng: the mother of fear, the bringer of suffering?

thag19.1:5.1.eng: Oh, when will I, seated on the lion’s throne,

thag19.1:5.2.eng: swiftly grasp the sword of the seers,

thag19.1:5.3.eng: forged by wisdom, of awesome might,

thag19.1:5.4.eng: and swiftly break Māra and his army? <j>When will it be?

thag19.1:6.1.eng: Oh, when will I be seen in the assemblies

thag19.1:6.2.eng: with those who are virtuous, unaffected, respecting the Dhamma,

thag19.1:6.3.eng: seeing things as they are, with faculties subdued?

thag19.1:7.1.pli: Kadā nu maṃ tandi khudā pipāsā,
thag19.1:7.1.eng: Oh, when will I focus on my heart’s goal <j>at the Mountainfold,

thag19.1:7.2.eng: free of oppression by laziness, hunger, thirst,

thag19.1:8.1.pli: Kadā nu kho yaṃ viditaṃ mahesinā,
thag19.1:8.1.eng: Oh, when will I, serene and mindful,

thag19.1:8.3.eng: that were realized by the great seer,

thag19.1:8.4.pli: Paññāya taṃ taṃ nu kadā bhavissati.
thag19.1:8.4.eng: and are so very hard to see? <j>When will it be?

thag19.1:9.1.pli: Kadā nu rūpe amite ca sadde,
thag19.1:9.1.eng: Oh, when will I, devoted to serenity,

thag19.1:9.2.eng: see with understanding the infinite sights,

thag19.1:9.3.eng: sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas

thag19.1:10.1.eng: Oh, when will I not be distraught

thag19.1:10.4.pli: Tuṭṭho na hessaṃ tadidaṃ kadā me.

thag19.1:11.1.pli: Kadā nu kaṭṭhe ca tiṇe latā ca,
thag19.1:11.1.eng: Oh, when will I discern the aggregates

thag19.1:11.2.eng: and the infinite varieties of phenomena,

thag19.1:11.3.eng: those interior and exterior, as no more than

thag19.1:11.4.eng: wood, grass, and creepers? <j>When will it be?

thag19.1:12.1.eng: Oh, when will the monsoon clouds in season

thag19.1:12.2.eng: freshly wet me in my robe in the forest,

thag19.1:12.3.eng: walking the path trodden by the seers?

thag19.1:13.1.eng: Oh, when will I rise up, <j>intent on attaining freedom from death,

thag19.1:13.3.eng: the cry of the crested peacock in the forest?

thag19.1:14.1.eng: Oh, when will I cross by psychic power unobstructed

thag19.1:14.3.eng: and that place where one is thrown in the abyss,
thag19.1:14.3.comm: “Mare’s mouth” is vaḷavāmukha, a mythical entrance to the underworld. Given that pātāla is also a term for the underworld, I take the line as a single expression.

thag19.1:14.4.eng: the horrifying Mare’s Mouth? When will it be?

thag19.1:15.1.eng: Oh, when will I be devoted to absorption,

thag19.1:15.2.eng: shunning all the signs of beauty,

thag19.1:15.3.eng: splitting apart desire for sensual stimulation,

thag19.1:15.4.pli: Jhāne yuto taṃ nu kadā bhavissati.
thag19.1:15.4.eng: like an elephant that wanders free of ties? <j>When will it be?

thag19.1:16.1.eng: Oh, when will I realize the teaching of the great seer

thag19.1:16.2.eng: and be content, like a pauper in debt

thag19.1:16.3.eng: harassed by creditors, who finds a hidden treasure?

thag19.1:17.1.eng: For many years you begged me,

thag19.1:17.2.eng: “Enough of living in a house for you!”

thag19.1:17.3.eng: Why do you not urge me on, mind,

thag19.1:17.4.eng: now that I’ve gone forth as an ascetic?

thag19.1:18.2.eng: “On the Mountainfold, the birds with colorful wings,

thag19.1:18.3.comm: Mahinda is “Great Indra”, the god of thunder.

thag19.1:18.4.eng: will delight you as you meditate in the forest?”

thag19.1:19.1.pli: Kulamhi mitte ca piye ca ñātake,
thag19.1:19.1.eng: In my family circle, friends, loved ones, and relatives;

thag19.1:19.2.eng: and in the world, sports and play, <j>and sensual pleasures;

thag19.1:19.3.eng: all these I gave up when I entered this life:

thag19.1:19.4.pli: Athopi tvaṃ citta na mayha tussasi.
thag19.1:19.4.eng: and even then you’re not content with me, mind!

thag19.1:20.1.pli: Mameva etaṃ na hi tvaṃ paresaṃ,
thag19.1:20.1.eng: This is mine alone, it doesn’t belong to others;

thag19.1:20.2.eng: when it is time to don your armor, why lament?

thag19.1:20.3.eng: Observing that all this is unstable,

thag19.1:20.4.eng: I went forth, seeking the state free of death.

thag19.1:21.1.eng: He whose words are well-composed , supreme among people,

thag19.1:21.2.eng: great physician, <j>guide for those who wish to train, said:

thag19.1:21.4.eng: so it’s very hard to control if you are not free of lust.”

thag19.1:22.1.eng: Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful;

thag19.1:22.2.eng: an ignorant ordinary person is bound to them.

thag19.1:22.3.eng: Seeking to be reborn again, they wish for suffering;

thag19.1:22.4.eng: led on by their mind, they’re banished to hell.

thag19.1:23.1.eng: “Staying in the grove resounding with cries

thag19.1:23.2.eng: of peacocks and herons, <j>and adorned by leopards and tigers,

thag19.1:23.3.eng: abandon concern for the body, without fail!”

thag19.1:23.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:24.2.eng: the powers, awakening factors, and immersion;

thag19.1:24.3.eng: realize the three knowledges <j>in the teaching of the Buddha!”

thag19.1:24.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:25.1.eng: “Develop the eightfold path <j>to realize freedom from death

thag19.1:25.2.eng: emancipating, its objective being the end of all suffering,

thag19.1:25.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:26.1.eng: “Reflect rationally on the aggregates as suffering,

thag19.1:26.2.pli: Yato ca dukkhaṃ samudeti taṃ jaha;
thag19.1:26.2.eng: and abandon that from which suffering arises;

thag19.1:26.3.eng: make an end of suffering in this very life!”

thag19.1:26.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:27.2.eng: that emptiness is non-self, and that gloom is death.

thag19.1:27.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:28.2.eng: seek alms amongst families, bowl in hand.

thag19.1:28.3.eng: Devote yourself to the word of the teacher, <j>the great seer!”

thag19.1:28.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:29.2.eng: mentally unchained to families and sensual pleasures,

thag19.1:29.3.eng: like the full moon on a bright night!”

thag19.1:29.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:30.2.eng: one who lives in charnel grounds, a rag-robe wearer,

thag19.1:30.3.eng: one who never lies down, <j>always delighting in ascetic practices.”

thag19.1:30.4.eng: So you used to urge me, mind.

thag19.1:31.1.eng: Mind, when you urge me to the impermanent and unstable,

thag19.1:31.2.eng: you’re acting like someone who plants trees,

thag19.1:31.3.eng: then, when they’re about to fruit,

thag19.1:31.4.eng: wishes to cut down the very same trees.

thag19.1:32.2.eng: I won’t do your bidding any more.

thag19.1:32.3.eng: Sensual pleasures are suffering, painful, <j>and very dangerous;

thag19.1:32.4.eng: I’ll wander with my mind <j>focused only on extinguishment.

thag19.1:33.1.eng: I didn’t go forth due to bad luck or shamelessness,

thag19.1:33.2.eng: or due to a whim or banishment,

thag19.1:33.3.eng: nor for the sake of a livelihood;

thag19.1:33.4.pli: Kato ca te citta paṭissavo mayā.
thag19.1:33.4.eng: it was because I agreed <j>to the promise you made, mind.

thag19.1:34.2.eng: the settling of suffering: these are praised by true persons.”

thag19.1:34.3.eng: So you used to urge me, mind,

thag19.1:34.4.eng: but now you keep on with your old habits!

thag19.1:35.1.eng: Craving, ignorance, the loved and unloved,

thag19.1:35.3.eng: and the delightful kinds of sensual stimulation:

thag19.1:35.4.eng: I’ve vomited them up, I can’t swallow them back.

thag19.1:36.1.pli: Sabbattha te citta vaco kataṃ mayā,
thag19.1:36.1.eng: I’ve done your bidding everywhere, mind!

thag19.1:36.2.eng: For many births, I’ve done nothing to upset you.

thag19.1:36.3.eng: Yet the creation in myself <j>is because of your ingratitude—
thag19.1:36.3.comm: Read akataññutāya. The “creation in myself” (ajjhattasambhavo) is craving.

thag19.1:36.4.eng: for a long time I’ve transmigrated <j>in the suffering you’ve made.

thag19.1:37.1.eng: Only you, mind, make a brahmin;

thag19.1:37.2.eng: you make an aristocrat or a royal seer.

thag19.1:37.3.pli: Vessā ca suddā ca bhavāma ekadā,
thag19.1:37.3.eng: Sometimes we become peasants or menials;

thag19.1:37.4.eng: and life as a god is also on account of you.

thag19.1:38.2.eng: because of you we’re born in hell.

thag19.1:38.4.eng: and life as a ghost is also on account of you.

thag19.1:39.1.eng: Come what may, you won’t betray me again,

thag19.1:39.2.eng: dazzling me with your ever-changing display!

thag19.1:39.3.eng: You play with me like I’m mad—

thag19.1:39.4.eng: but how have I ever failed you, mind?

thag19.1:40.1.eng: In the past my mind wandered

thag19.1:40.2.eng: how it wished, where it liked, as it pleased.

thag19.1:40.4.eng: as a trainer with a hook guides a rutting elephant.

thag19.1:41.1.eng: The teacher willed that this world appear to me

thag19.1:41.3.eng: Mind, let me leap into the victor’s teaching,

thag19.1:41.4.eng: carry me over the great flood, so hard to pass.

thag19.1:42.1.pli: Na te idaṃ citta yathā purāṇakaṃ,

thag19.1:42.2.eng: Nothing could make me return to your control!

thag19.1:42.3.eng: I’ve gone forth in the teaching of the great seer,

thag19.1:42.4.eng: those like me don’t come to ruin.

thag19.1:43.2.eng: the four quarters, the intermediate directions, <j>below and in the sky;

thag19.1:43.3.eng: the three realms of existence are all impermanent and harried—

thag19.1:43.4.eng: where can you go to find happiness, mind?

thag19.1:44.1.eng: Mind, what will you do to someone <j>who has made the ultimate commitment?

thag19.1:44.2.eng: Nothing could make me a follower <j>under your control, mind;

thag19.1:44.3.eng: I’d never touch a bellows <j>with a mouth open at each end;

thag19.1:44.4.eng: curse this mortal frame flowing with nine streams!

thag19.1:45.1.eng: You’ve ascended the mountain peak, <j>full of nature’s beauty,

thag19.1:45.3.eng: a grove sprinkled with fresh water in the monsoon;

thag19.1:45.4.eng: and there you’ll be happy in your cave-home.

thag19.1:46.1.eng: Peacocks with beautiful necks and crests,

thag19.1:46.3.eng: crying out at the resounding thunder:

thag19.1:46.4.eng: they’ll delight you as you meditate in the forest.

thag19.1:47.1.eng: When the heavens have rained, <j>and the grass is four inches high,

thag19.1:47.2.eng: and the grove is full of flowers like a cloud,

thag19.1:47.3.eng: between the mountains, like the fork of a tree, I’ll lie;

thag19.1:47.4.eng: it will be as soft as cotton-buds.

thag19.1:48.1.eng: I’ll act rather as a master does:

thag19.1:48.2.pli: Yaṃ labbhati tenapi hotu me alaṃ;
thag19.1:48.2.eng: let whatever I get be enough for me.

thag19.1:48.3.eng: And that’s why I’ll make you as supple

thag19.1:48.4.eng: as a tireless worker makes a cat-skin bag.

thag19.1:49.1.eng: I’ll act rather as a master does:

thag19.1:49.2.pli: Yaṃ labbhati tenapi hotu me alaṃ;
thag19.1:49.2.eng: let whatever I get be enough for me.

thag19.1:49.3.eng: I’ll control you with my energy,

thag19.1:49.4.eng: as a skilled trainer controls an elephant with a hook.

thag19.1:50.1.eng: Now that you’re well-tamed and reliable,

thag19.1:50.2.eng: I can use you, <j>like a trainer uses a straight-running horse,

thag19.1:50.3.eng: to practice the path of grace,

thag19.1:50.4.eng: cultivated by those who take care of their minds.

thag19.1:51.1.eng: I shall strongly fasten you to a meditation subject,
thag19.1:51.1.comm: This is a rare early use of ārammaṇa in the sense “support for” (i.e. “subject of”) meditation.

thag19.1:51.2.eng: as an elephant is tied to a post with firm rope.

thag19.1:51.3.eng: You’ll be well-guarded by me, <j>well-developed by mindfulness,

thag19.1:51.4.eng: and unattached to rebirth in all states of existence.

thag19.1:52.1.eng: With wisdom you’ll cut short <j>the one following the wrong path,

thag19.1:52.2.eng: curb them by meditation, <j>and settle them on the right path.

thag19.1:52.3.eng: Having seen arising and passing away <j>with respect to the cause of suffering,
thag19.1:52.3.comm: Take samudayaṁ as accusative of relation, equivalent to locative (although treated as genitive in commentary).

thag19.1:52.4.eng: you’ll be an heir to the greatest teacher.

thag19.1:53.1.eng: Under the sway of the four distortions, mind,

thag19.1:53.2.eng: you dragged me around like a bull in a pit;

thag19.1:53.3.eng: but now you won’t associate <j>with the great sage of compassion,

thag19.1:53.4.eng: the cutter of fetters and bonds?

thag19.1:54.1.eng: Like a deer roaming free in the colorful forest,

thag19.1:54.2.eng: I’ll ascend the lovely mountain <j>wreathed in monsoon clouds,

thag19.1:54.3.eng: and rejoice to be on that hill, free of folk—

thag19.1:54.4.eng: there is no doubt you’ll perish, mind.

thag19.1:55.1.eng: The men and women who live <j>under your will and command,

thag19.1:55.2.pli: Narā ca nārī ca anubhonti yaṃ sukhaṃ;

thag19.1:55.3.eng: they are ignorant and fall under Māra’s control;

thag19.1:55.4.eng: loving life, they’re your disciples, mind.

thag2.1:1.4.eng: and pass away, again and again.

thag2.1:2.2.eng: I have no need for another life.

thag2.1:2.4.eng: and attained the ending of defilements.

thag2.1:2.5.pli: Itthaṃ sudaṃ āyasmā uttaro thero gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
thag2.1:2.5.eng: That is how these verses were recited by the senior venerable Uttara.

thag2.10:1.4.eng: like one who kills birds using a dead bird as a decoy.

thag2.10:2.1.eng: A brahmin’s color is not on the outside;

thag2.10:2.2.eng: a brahmin is colored on the inside.

thag2.10:2.4.eng: is truly a dark one, Sujampati.

thag2.11:1.1.eng: It’s from eagerness to learn that learning grows;

thag2.11:1.3.eng: by wisdom, you know the goal;

thag2.11:2.2.eng: and practice to be released from fetters.

thag2.11:2.3.eng: If you don’t find enjoyment there,

thag2.11:2.4.eng: live in the Saṅgha, self-protected and mindful.

thag2.12:1.1.comm: The reading and derivation of veṭhamissena are unclear. Veṭha means “twist, strap, turban”. Missa means “mixed” or “plaited” (Bu Ss 2:2.1.21. Thus it probably refers to a kind of strong twisted material used to tie or bind, i.e. rope.

thag2.12:1.4.eng: hurting them in all kinds of ways—

thag2.12:1.5.eng: they’re treated in the same way;

thag2.12:2.3.eng: they are the heir to each

thag2.13:1.1.eng: The days and nights rush by,

thag2.13:1.2.eng: and then life is cut short.

thag2.13:1.3.eng: The life of mortals wastes away,

thag2.13:1.4.eng: like the water in tiny streams.

thag2.13:2.4.eng: for the result will be bad for them.
